Execute Commands

You'll learn how to:

  • Remotely execute shell commands on managed systems
  • Remotely execute Salt commands on managed systems

Estimated time: 5 minutes

Difficulty:

After you install SaltStack, you are immediately ready to run shell commands, update packages, and distribute files to all managed systems simultaneously. As a bonus, all responses are returned in a consistent, configurable format so you can easily see what did and didnâ€™t work.

10 minutes to measurable productivity? Not bad.

Command Syntax

Salt commands are executed using a common structure:

target: Determines which systems receive the command. Uses hostname globbing by default, but there are many other ways to select and filter that we'll get into later. For now, it is enough to know that '*' targets all managed systems.

command: This is how you leverage the real power of Salt. Commands consist of a module.function, and Salt comes with built-in commands to install software, copy files, check services, and most other tasks you want to automate.

arguments: Provides any extra data needed by module.function. For example, the package.installed command likes to know which package you want to install. You tell it using an argument.

Run a Shell Command

Salt lets you remotely run shell commands across multiple systems using cmd.run:

salt '*' cmd.run 'ls -l'

All managed systems simultaneously and immediately execute this command and return the output to the master. Feeling the power?

Salt Commands

While shelling out using cmd.run is certainly useful, the real power of remote execution comes when you add Salt command modules. The Salt community has put tremendous effort into creating command modules that simplify most management tasks, and even better, the same command can be used consistently across all platforms.

Resist the urge to shell out. Learn the ways of the Salt commands.

Show Disk Usage

salt '*' disk.usage

Install a Package

salt '*' pkg.install vim

List network interfaces

salt '*' network.interfaces

These are just a few examples of the many commands available. Take a look at the full list of modules for a list.
